content.description: Bouldery moves off the ground lead to fun, less-than-vertical face climbing on good edges that will continue to clean up with time. Moderate climbing until you get to seventh bolt. Enjoy the business above!
content.location: Obvious bolt line on the face to the climbers right of Anchors from Hell.

climbs.name: Unnamed Sport Climb #1
climbs.fa: Will Hair and Jose Parara, around 1993

content.description: Climb up on a rounded ledge to clip the first bolt. Climb lower angle face and arete with bad feet with crux coming at bolts 4-5. A nice rest around the corner appears after that. Continue up using the arete and crimps with a nice jug but no feet to clip the anchor. Very fun. Overall felt hard 11.
content.protection: 10 or so bolts. 60m rope should be plenty. We used a 70.
content.location: Located between old bushmills and anchor from hell. Obvious bolted sport climb.

content.description: The obvious sport route between the unknown 5.8+ and the 5.7 finger crack. The rock is a bit crumbly, but the moves are fun. Shares an anchor with the 5.7 finger crack to the right.
content.location: Between the 5.8+ offwidth route and the 5.7 finger crack. Easily identifiable with bolts every 4 feet at the bottom.

content.description: Starts on thin .3 and .2 crack. When that ends step right over lip to hand crack followed by good jugs to rap rings on your left.

Route Description:

This is a right facing dihedral with an obvious roof about 25 feet up, left of Old Bushmills and right of Lite Not Solid. Scramble up the large boulder close to the start of Bushmills and belay from the block at the base of the climb (single belay bolt).

Climb ~25ft of good hands to a roof. Traverse to the lip, pull past, and enjoy tight hands and off fingers for ~60ft. Above, the dihedral throws a tightening bulge for about ten feet (crux). Once past the bulge, keep it together for the varied climbing to the anchors.

One of the best and cleanest routes in Pine Canyon.

Doable with a single 70 meter rope ONLY if belaying from high up on pillar/boulder.
content.protection: Numerous pieces in the tight hands rattly fingers range.  Handful of hands and a few down to a blue tcu and a few up to a 3.5 camalot.  Two bolt anchor.

content.description:
Pine Creek Wall! A few hundred feet down from main routes (

Old Bushmills

and

Anchors From Hell

).  Climbs like a face through a steep scoop at the top.  It has a plaque at the bottom. Needs a repeat, super worth doing.
content.protection: All the pro is .1 Camalots and purple TCU's.

content.description: Start in hands up to a pod.  From pod to the top it's off width. Rap rings are just above the crack and to the right. Good holds out of the crack keep it easier.
content.location: Route is right of the topo photo. Just left of a thin slab crack climb.

climbs.name: Pickles and Milk
climbs.fa: F.A. Tyler Phillips  5.8+ A1(rope solo) 10/15/07                              F.F.A. Tyler P. Luke Douglas, Zack Garhard 10/16/07

content.description: Surmount the chockstone and clip a bolt above it. Chimney your way up very featured rock passing another bolt to a big shelf. From here clip your way up really cool varnished desert pockets to a sandy hollow jug, from the jug find the best sloper and rock your way up onto a really nice view and optional belay. From 2 bolt rap/belay hop your way across the "bumps" to the big shelf below the sandy summit. One bolt protects the "summit" moves (5.7+). No anchor exists on the summit, downclimb.
content.protection: 7 QD's should suffice, a lousy #1 camalot placement exists above the crux bolt if you are so inclined. If your running it as one pitch expect rope drag and bring lots of long runners. I recommend doing it as 1 1/2 pitches.
content.location: Start in the gash facing the road on the Player Hater Bumps formation. As you gaze back into Pine Canyon from the road the route sits on the right shoulder of the canyon. Look for the window in the rock.

content.description: Thin fingers lead to bad sized hand/finger 1.5 friends.  Small pockets allow stances for gear placements.  Catch your breath halfway up and finish tight hands to the anchors 2 friends.
content.protection: Many .75 camalots or 1.5 friends for the bottom half, then 2 friends for the top.  The top seems to be between .75-1 camalots.  Round it out with a couple of tcu's for the beginning.

content.description:
Climb the sandy chimney system up and around the right side of the buttress with the short hand crack on the face.

Mostly sandy off-width and chimney climbing with a spicy section of loose blocks in the gully at the top. A good cave at the base protects the belayer from the rain of choss.
content.protection: Single set of camalots, doubles of #5 and #6 could be nice.

content.description: Left of "Taco Terror". Start on the left edge of the shelf and climb past three good bolts through the overhanging, slightly loose base, left and then up. Follow the right-facing dihedral past bulges until it is possible to step into the widening crack on the right. Follow this to a hanging belay 160'. A spectacular finish to a great climb!
content.protection: Two or three of everything .75-3, save a 1,2,3 Camalot for the final airy crack.

content.description: Two cruxes.  One down low to get above the bolt and one up high to get into the 'V'
content.protection: Standard rack plus doubles of small stuff below #1 camalot.  I think you could place two #3's if you would like.
content.location: From Anchors from Hell, this is the 4th route to climber's right that has anchors as of 9/16/14.  Easily recognized by the graffiti chipping 'KRGA'

content.description:
A real gem of a pitch with varied and interesting movement throughout.

Make easy moves past one bolt and continue up through a mellow chimney. Then, shift gears as the chimney narrows to a shallow slot with thin, parallel cracks on either side. Make unique movements through this section, pull over a thin bulge, and finish by wiggling up a very casual off-width section to the chains.

Note: be careful pulling your rope - recommended to lower/rap on the face to climber's left of the pitch and pull from there.
content.protection:
Doubles: .5-#3.

Singles: .2-.4, #4, & #5.

Handful of runners to extend some pieces.
content.location: Around the corner to the west (climber's left) of KRGA.

content.description:
This is an excellent, varied route with some difficult finger crack jamming. It's often overlooked despite its proximity to classics, such as Taco Terror.

Start with awkward moves pulling into a flare with a finger crack in the back. Chimney/jam up the flare to its end and jam a thin finger crack through a small rough, with feet. Hand jam up small left-facing corner to a stance below the final fingers splitter. Bust up this finger crack with hard moves separated by a few marginal stances.

You can lead/rap this route with one 70 meter rope. It's really close though so watch the ends. The climb is probably 37 meters long, but with rope stretch, you're good.
content.protection: Take a ton of cams in the 1-1.5 inch size (e.g. .5 camalots, orange metolious, #1 and #1.5 friends).  Take a few small TCUs and a few hand sized pieces, up to a #4 friend (for the middle section).
content.location: About 100 yards left of Rabid Muslim and Lite Not Solid.  Look for a finger-crack flare that's about 15 feet right of a large, broken right facing corner.  The anchors are hard to see way up on the face at the end of the splitter finger crack.

content.description:
This is a nice splitter crack that starts with off fingers, leading to hands. The final 15 feet is protected by two bolts.

The really cool thing about this route, is there are quite a few foot possibilities outside of the crack; keeping the grade moderate instead of more difficult.

You don't need a million cams. One each from #.5 BD to #2 yellow plus and additional #2. Start off in a 1.25" crack (purple BD or DMM) gradually getting larger until it's about 2.5" (yellow #2 BD or #4 DMM). I like to have two yellows near the end. The two bolt boulder problem is quite fun and ends on a nice ledge.
content.protection: .5 to 2 BD Camalots with extra #2. Two quickdraws for the two bolts and two more for the anchors.
content.location: Locate the route with the huge cowboy initials, KRGA. To the right is a stack of huge broken boulders leaning against the main cliff. Go along the base of these huge boulders heading to the right (going further up into Pine Canyon) and passing 4 other climbs. Head around the right side of the boulders and head up to the main wall. Nestled behind the boulders is this climb, you can't miss this splitter and Mrs. Renfro's Revenge to the left of it.

content.description: This is a finger dihedral broken up with occasional hands and face holds.  Jamming, liebacking, and stemming make for fun, physical climbing.
content.protection: Cams up to a #3 camalot and doubles in the tcu range. New big fat coward bolt added near the top not by FA.
